title: Twitter sued Indian government for ‘arbitrarily’ silencing critics. It lost.
description: A judge in the Karnataka High Court dismissed Twitter’s lawsuit and ordered the company to pay a fine for taking up the court's time.

title: South Korea’s biggest Pride parade was blocked. It came back stronger.
description: When Seoul's Pride organizers were denied a permit, they found an alternate venue and route as a reminder that they "are living, working and loving alongside you.”

title: Chinese tour bus, mayor’s home attacked as protests roil France
description: Vincent Jeanbrun said his family was sleeping as protesters attacked his house with a burning vehicle. The police killing of Nahel M. sparked protests nationwide.

title: Dutch king apologizes for monarchy’s role in colonial slave trade
description: King Willem-Alexander apologized as the Netherlands marked 150 years since the practical abolition of slavery in Suriname and the former Dutch Caribbean.

title: Ukraine live briefing: Zelensky says Spanish leader’s trip on first day heading E.U. council marks ‘new reality’
description: The Ukrainian president said the visit to Kyiv was “symbolic” and underscored the “priorities of the Spanish presidency and our cooperation.”

title: Ukraine says Putin is planning a nuclear disaster. These people live nearby.
description: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant has been in danger throughout the conflict, but the risks of a meltdown rose sharply with the destruction of the Kakhovka dam.

title: Carlos Alberto Montaner, Cuban exile writer who battled Castro, dies at 80
description: Mr. Montaner initially celebrated Fidel Castro's takeover of Cuba but quickly turned into a fierce critic.
